p: C. abortus was recorded only in sheep (5; 0.75%) with no significant correlation ( p > 0.05). Its prevalence was higher among males (4; 0.6%) than females (1; 0.15%). Also, it was higher among local (3; 0.45%) than (2; 0.3%) imported ones, with no significant correlation ( p > 0.05). The prevalence of C. abortus accordingly the animalâ€™s source was (3; 0.45%) in sheep from the veterinary clinic and (2; 0.3%) from the private farms ( Table 2).
